moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4 exd4: The Center Game, a very old-fashioned opening. White either loses time recapturing or has to play a kind of gambit.
moves.4. Bc4 Nc6 5. c3: Definitely a gambit now, as White offers the Pawn exchange locking in Black's material gain in return for a quick, provocative attack.
moves.5... dxc3: Black is a man of honor: he must accept the gambit.
moves.6. Bxf7+: Very risky. White was apparently in a tactical, attacking mood.
moves.9... Qe8 10. O-O Qxe4: Now Black is pressing forward. He regains the material advantage.
moves.11. Re1 Qg6 12. Qb3 Nf6 13. Nc3: White is down a Pawn, but Black's exposed K position and immobile KR are weaknesses. It's hard to tell who has the advantage.
moves.13... h6 14. Be3 Bg4: Both men complete their development, clearing the last minor pieces off the first rank.
moves.15. Nh4 Qh5 16. Qxb7: Black had overlooked this fork, which wins a piece and gives White the material edge... momentarily.
moves.16... Rb8 17. Qxc6: White thinks he's just won a piece, but he in turn had overlooked...
moves.18. Qxc7 Rxb2: In his eagerness to snatch back the Pawn, Black leaves his first rank undefended.
moves.19. Qc8+ Kf7 20. Qxh8: White pounces, winning the Rook. In turn, he has to be careful not to get his Q trapped on the 8th rank.
moves.20... Bd7 21. Re2 Rb7 22. Qa8 Bc6 23. Qc: Cleverly avoiding the discovery [...R-N8 ch RxR (or NxR) ...BxQ]
moves.23... Qc4 24. Rc1 Re7 25. Rcc2 Rd7: Despite being down a whole Rook, Black fights on gamely.
moves.26. Ne4 Qd5 27. Red2 Qxe4 28. Qxc6: With every pair of pieces that vanish, White's Rook advantage gets that much bigger.
moves.28... d5 29. h3 Qf5 30. Bd4 Ne4 31. Rde2: White continues to press, also looking for ways to simplify and exchange down.
moves.35... Re7 36. Rc7: Forcing the exchange of Black's last Rook.
moves.36... Rxc7 37. Qxc7+ Kg6 38. fxe4: With the fall of the Knight, Black could easily resign here. However, he plays it out to the end.
